I paid for the subscription. Everything seemed fine for a while until today. I go to put some new games on my daughter's tablet and I can't exit the app to get to the play store. It's acknowledging that it is the correct pin, It pretends that it's going to exit, then it won't exit. So I try to send an email for support and it won't do that from the app either. Okayyy. So then I change the settings to not come back on after a reboot. Well sure enough it comes back on anyway despite the change in settings. I changed the home screen setting to not come back on when you push the home screen middle button and after trying 15 times it finally randomly exits the ap. Yay! oh but the home screen button still brings me back. What? So I end up just trying over and over to exit and when it finally does I get to the settings and disable the app and delete it to finally get control of the tablet back. This app was behaving like a virus. Once the app was deleted the tablet started going faster too. If I had not paid for the subscription I probably would have just been annoyed and not written a review but I paid for this ya'll.

Youtube and youtube kids has a lot of completely unsuitable brainless rubbish that I do not want them having access to and even if you select their age it can bring up content I deem unsuitable. No choice but to pay now...OK. Bad mood. Must go through my account as kids can not even access google services. So it says it will cost $5.99.... click buy and then price changes at the final screen to $12.99? OK, now I paid... oops they use a buggy method of logging that premium upgrade.... the kids accounts do not show premium...restricted so "restore" purchase will never work. Had to wipe all game saves etc. for each kid and remake accounts. Even then still had to try "restore" multiple times before it agreed I paid. And who knows future re-installs. EDIT: Shortened up & +star for reply. Will not be asking for refund; not worth more time and might as well have latest version for future instead of trading the fix of one issue with a special apk only to be outdated by next upgrade. Edit 2: the developer has been helpful. We've determined that the issue is not related to this app but because of something in Gmail opening web links inside Gmail. Turning off that option fixes the problem. I will be writing Google! Edit 1: 5 minutes after sending the email complaint, I received a response and am now communicating with the developer to attempt to fix the problem. Original post: I received the email to register for an account and when I pressed the button to confirm my email address, it took me to a page that offered other apps that work with this one. Each one I chose took me to a page with different notices and alerts like my device has a virus and to install their virus cleaner or I won a prize. This is a bad practice to lure people into downloading malware. I am extremely disappointed with this company that is supposed to help me keep my kids safe but in reality is trying to take advantage of people that wouldn't know better. I also sent this as a complaint to the company email. "dinner time" might be a better option if you care about yours and your child's privacy and security.

The launcher works well and keeps the kids from accessing unapproved apps (even from the history and notifications). However, I paid extra for the timer, and that doesn't seem to work at all. I meticulously set time limits for apps and categories, but the enforcement of those limits is extremely inconsistent. It's still a good app for locking kids out of certain apps, but the extra $5 for the timer was, unfortunately, a waste of money (except to support the developer, so not a huge waste). Also, less important but still annoying, the process of setting up and configuring multiple profiles is exceptionally non-intuitive and time consuming, and switching between accounts requires proficiency in reading (so, works best with older kids).

It's still easy to hack out of if you have a gifted kid.  Here's 2 ways to get out of Kids Place mode without requiring the kids place password.   Please fix these loopholes!  1.  When you lightly press the power button to turn off the screen, and then lightly press it again to turn the screen back on, you can see the little "guest user icon" on the top right of the screen (even with notification bar lock set to on).   This happens no matter what setting I have enable in Kids Place.  2.  Same original problem.  When you lightly press the power button to turn off the screen, and then lightly press it again to turn the screen back on, you have ability to press the camera button, and from there you can exit out of the camera mode back into your "adult" android mode.  So basically I had to go into developer mode in android and disable the guest user mode function in order to eliminate this workaround.   But I shouldn't have to do this....  1/4/17 UPDATE:   now my son figured out he can swipe from far right to left to access another menu (it seems to bring up homepage menu - contacts, etc.).   Is there a way to disable this?

I think, since purchasing this app, I've had to configure about 10 things at different times over 7 days.  Those 10 configurations have required me to enter my password over 100 times.  Devs, please, get a handle on this, the UI is really very bad.  The app does exactly what I want, but actually coercing it into doing that is like pulling teeth.  Post software update update (Dec 2016): The interface is no better.  And having tried to use it for many months I'm sorry to say that its not possible to reliably block the kids from running apps.  We have Kids Place running (the app is on in the tray) and yet the kids can start apps we have expressly tried to ban in the UI.  We try to restrict their access to 1 hour per day, but two hours later we find them squirrelled away in a corner playing the apps we believed we banned using this application.  We bought Kids Place believing it would make our lives easier: it has done the opposite.  Kids Place is frustrating-as-hell and not fit for purpose.  If you're buying your kids a new tablet for Christmas 2016, I'd steer clear of this app.  If I could give it zero stars I would.

I had an issue with access to apps on my blocked list but the development team did a great job resolving my issue in a quick manner.   If you are able to access open apps that are blocked through the change app feature on Android (square button next to home button) please try the following.  1. Exit Kids Place.  2. Go to device settings > security > App with Usage Access (typically at bottom of security settings section) and there please check the option of Kids Place. Please note this option may vary from device to device so if you don't see it there, you may have to look around in your device settings.  3. Once you have enabled this, please restart Kids Place and test it. This should fix it.

To date, I still use this app (and a bunch of the associated plugins) and a few others by this developer. I've been using this app ever since it came out.   Around 2011, I was looking for a solution to turn my older phones into non-phones that my very young children could use safely and age-appropriately. Until this app came out, I resorted to rooting, flashing and trying to customize my devices. This app has been a time-saver and an excellent way to hand a device to a child with complete peace-of-mind. For instance, the addition of the feature to disable wifi for each app (you can customize which app the child can access) has been invaluable. The time-limit and scheduler works perfectly.  However, more than just the functionality of the app, the developers are outstanding. They have been very quick to respond to my numerous emails and questions. They've bent over backwards to help with my particular configuration. One time, I even got a response from someone while they were about to go on vacation!   All in all, I highly recommend this developer's suite of apps for anyone with young children.

Here is how to hack it kids. 1 Boot into safe mode by holding the poweroff button. On the screen you will see some options. Hold down the poweroff option, do not just tap it. The device will say, boot into safe mode? Select yes. Next time you boot, parental controls will not run and you can uninstall it. After uninstalling it you can go back to normal. Booting into safe mode varies from device to device. You can google to see how. Boot means to start your device. 2. This way will certainly work but will reset your device. Boot into recovery mode by turning your device off. After your device is off, Hold the volume down button first than press the power button while holding both buttons at the same time until the device starts up or volume up button first than press the power button second while holding both at the same time until the device starts up. You will get into a screen that has these options: Reboot into recovery, Reboot system now, and Fastboot. Using the volume up and down keys, select reboot into recovery. Select wipe cache partition. Next, select, wipe user data After that select reboot system now. You have an unrestricked device! I rated 2* because it was fun hacking.

PROs: I have 4 Android devices and they all have this app.  You can set up Kids place with a pin code to adjust settings, add apps for them to access, and to exit the app.  It even will lock the kids in the app if it was activated and the power was reset.  It gives you a lot of options, like Block calls or turn on airplane mode.  I do not use ether of these modes on my phone.  But it helps save power on my kids tablet!  When I log out of kids place, I get my WiFi back and do whatever I want on the standard launcher (Update apps, change settings,add new apps, etc).  Before I give the tablet back to the kids, I put it into Kids Place and it locks them out of the main Android OS.  Keeps them off the internet! CONs:  I don't know if this can be fixed, because of the protection that is necessary with Kids Place.  But if you open an app like Angry Birds, and there is an internet advertisement.  The app will just close since the app cannot hit the internet and may need something that I have not given Kids Place access to.  Then if the app is reopened, then it starts where it last left off.  Which is the advertisement, then closes the app again. The only work around is to exit Kids Place.

Kids Place is a really simple and effective app that enables you as a parent to lock your down your Nexus tablet to the Kids place screen. The app doesn't lock you in to its own games and you can simply choose any apps you want to make available for your child. Another really great part is the additional Kids Place Video player that allows you control access to only the videos that you want to child to see from You Tube. You can also easily revert to your normal Nexus home screen via a 4 digit pin. Cant rate Kids Place highly enough after trying and removing several other parental control applications. Its also appears to be free so far!!
This app is the best. I love being able to confidently let my 3yr old play with my phone without having to worry about him accidently deleting or buying things he shouldn't. I highly recommend it!!

First Review I've ever done on Android market app, but I've been using all apps for over 2 years.  I'm so impressed with this app and how it modifies your tablet to be set to use only for children.  If an ad appears in a program, this app will prevent your youngster from navigating away from that app to the add, which makes this feature beneficial if you need time to do something around the house and you want your child to focus on an educational app and not need you to come over to assist them in order to get back to the app they were originally working from.  Usually I only use ad-free apps in order to prevent this from occurring.  Another great option is the ability to pre-select apps to display on the screen that you want your child to use, without your adult apps being mixed in.  I can't believe I didn't pay for this apps.  I've tried many child lock apps and launchers designed for children, but nothing comes anywhere close to how great this App is.   5 Stars.  If this software company made their own tablet, I would buy it.  Thank You Kiddoware!

Awesome app for controlling access, but I'd like to see two things on top of the existing features: * multiple  accounts.  I have 3 kids in my home aged 5 (twins) and 6. They all have their preferred apps. Having a way to create different profiles for each one would facilitate access...  *better Time management capabilities Having a timer for locking access is good as a starting point. But I'd like to see an actual scheduler (unable to use between 7pm and 8AM, after 5pm only, etc.), a time quota consumption per profile (1 hour per day for the young ones, 2 hours for the big girl, indication of how much time they have left for the day, etc.)   With these two features added, you have a killer Kid's corner app! And very happy and thankful parents... I'd be more than happy to pay a few of bucks for the peace of mind and the added features... :)

The app works as expected. Good job done by the developer. That said, I find the interface very basic.  I installed it on my daughters phone so that I could lock down YouTube etc but still let her use the phone as originally intended. It should feel more like the phone interface with sliding screens changeable wallpaper and resizable high quality icons, etc.  It feels simple and aimed at very young kids but my 11yr old daughter hates it. I installed Go Launcher and enabled it through the app.  The app still works and blocks all but the allowed apps and only permits the Kids Place to be used as the default Home screen. The Go Launcher needs to be launched from within the app. One big problem, the timer completely locks the phone. Can't even use the phone as a phone.  Change the UI, make the timer customisable, ie let the administrator decide when the phone can/can't be used, blocked during the school day for instance, and this will become a great app. then it will be worthy of 5 stars.

I recently converted two old phones for exclusive use of my 6 and 3 year old boys. With Kids Place in effect, they're locked down from accessing anything other than what I chose to give them access to. Since I don't allow them access to a web browser or the play store, they can't access any new apps or anything on the internet (that uses a browser.)  I did have one problem. The apps I selected weren't showing up after I rebooted the phone. This was happening for any app installed on the SD card. I emailed the developers and they provided a fix within a couple days.   My only lasting complaint is that I wish this was a $0.99 or $1.99 app with a lite version so I could reward them for their good work.  The phones we're using are a Nexus 1 and an EVO 4G. The Nexus is relatively stock, but the EVO has Cyanogenmod 7 on it so my 6 year old can use Google Talk to video chat with his grandparents (and me at work!)  Since we've done this, we find that the 6 year old is spending more time reading and writing (he loves to send IMs to us) and he's exploring with Maps, Earth, Astronomy apps, etc. The three year old is having fun, even when he's just pretending he's smarter than a 6y.o.
No problems so far!
